main event: A bright, circular object was observed by multiple ground observers at RAF Station, Upper Heyford, England on March 10, 1961.
interesting points: The object was described as being bright white or yellowish in color, and approximately 2 feet in diameter.
The object was observed in relation to the ground and remained stationary during the entire 10-minute sighting period.
The object was tracked by radar, which indicated it was moving slowly at first on a heading of 030 degrees, then turned to 100 degrees before contact was lost.
Attempts to intercept the object with an aircraft were unsuccessful, and no known aircraft or balloons were present in the area at the time.

The weather conditions were overcast with some haze and ground fog, but the observers consistently described the object as very bright, which could not be easily accounted for by a temperature inversion or cloud formations.
witnesses: control tower operator, air police, security, and weather observers
